awd_titl_txt: 2022 Graduate Climate Conference (GCC); Eatonville, Washington; October 28-30, 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 16th Graduate Climate Conference (GCC), planned for 28-30 October 2022 at the Charles L. Pack Conference Center. The conference is annually and alternates between Woods Hole the University of Washington.

The GCC is an interdisciplinary climate conference organized entirely by and for graduate students. It provides a discussion forum for students conducting research on climate in a variety of disciplines including atmospheric dynamics, ocean dynamics, ocean biology and chemistry, atmospheric chemistry, climate dynamics, paleoclimate, and human dimensions of climate variability and change. The meeting is intended to help students familiarize themselves with the breadth of climate science, gain exposure to the enormous range of tools available to address climate-related questions, and understand how their research fits into the broader landscape of current climate science. The conference seeks to better prepare graduate students for scientific inquiry in a field that increasingly demands interdisciplinary approaches. Funds provided here support travel and subsistence for 120 students chosen through a competitive process which places emphasis on selecting a cross-section of applicants that reflects the diversity of the next generation of scientists

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 16th annual Graduate Climate Conference (GCC) was held on October 28-30, 2022 at the University of Washington Pack Forest Conference Center.  The GCC provided a discussion forum for graduate students undertaking research on climate and climate change in an array of disciplines, including atmospheric, biological, earth, ocean, and social sciences. The conference covered 14 different topics:

  1. Polar climate
  2. Carbon cycle
  3. Biogeochemical cycling
  4. Climate change in sensitive regions
  5. Climate variability, from seasonal to orbital timescales
  6. Proxy development
  7. Environmental management and agriculture
  8. Hydrology and geomorphology
  9. Ecoclimate and biological responses to climate change
  10. Ocean heat content & large-scale circulation
  11. Extreme events
  12. Tropical dynamics and convection
  13. Atmospheric Chemistry
  14. Clouds, radiation, and climate sensitivity. 
  15. Urban design and climate policy & solutions
  16. Social impacts of climate change

 These topics were covered in seven oral presentation sessions and four poster presentation sessions including 28 oral and 74 poster presentations. The GCC also offered five professional development workshops:

  • "Social responsibility of Earth scientists"
  • "Making grad school applications more accessible via peer mentorship" 
  • "Designing effective and inclusive outreach for K-12 students"
  • "Data visualization"
  • "Machine Learning Skills for Climate Applications"

 In addition, the GCC hosted two keynote speakers. The GCC provided ample opportunities for training and professional development for both the organizing team as well as attendees of the conference. The conference was attended by 101 graduate students from a total of 36 different fields and 37 institutions across the U.S. and internationally. 56% of participants of the GCC 2022 used she/her pronouns, and 11% of attendees came from under-represented minorities.
